newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatian court rules railway strike illegal.
newsitem.headline: Croatian court rules railway strike illegal.

text.p: Croatia's supreme court on Monday ruled a 12-day-old railway workers' strike illegal but rail union leaders vowed to continue a scaled-down stoppage until the decision becomes legally binding, Croatian radio said.
Union officials said they would appeal against the ruling to Croatia's appellate court, which will have to decide on the appeal within eight days.
The supreme court said the union failure to obey an order issued by the transport ministry to maintain minimal rail services had rendered the strike illegal, the state-run radio reported.
In an anticipation of the court's ruling, unions resumed cargo services earlier on Monday, but only on a skeleton basis.
Passenger traffic had already been restarted on December 4 in what the strikers said was a sign of goodwill.
The strike began on November 28, when workers stopped all but military trains to demand higher wages and better working conditions.
The government, faced with a wave of unrest, refused to give in and said there was no money to increase pay this year.
The government is expected to spend more than one billion kuna ($200 million) in 1996 alone to subsidise the loss-making state-owned Croatian Railways.
